title: API Reference
text:
Use import justembed as je. Version 0.1.1.









Function
Description




je.register_workspace(path)
Register a workspace (does not delete data)


je.deregister_workspace(path, confirm=True)
Remove from registry


je.list_workspaces()
List registered workspaces













Function
Description




je.begin(workspace, port=5424, host="127.0.0.1")
Start server (blocks)


je.begin(..., background=True)
Start in background


je.begin(..., open_browser=True)
Open browser after start


je.terminate(port)
Stop server


je.list_servers()
List active servers













Function
Description




je.train_model(name, training_data, embedding_dim=128, max_features=5000)
Train custom model. training_data = file path or list of strings


je.list_models()
List models (default E5 + custom)


je.delete_model(name, confirm=True)
Delete custom model













Function
Description




je.create_kb(name, model="default")
Create KB. model = "default" (E5) or custom model name


je.list_kbs()
List KBs with model and chunk count


je.delete_kb(name, confirm=True)
Delete KB













Function
Description




je.add(kb, path=...)
Add file or folder (.txt, .md)


je.add(kb, text=...)
Add raw text


je.add(kb, paths=[...])
Add multiple files


je.add(kb, documents=[{"text": "...", "filename": "..."}])
Add from dicts


je.add(..., max_tokens=300, merge_threshold=50)
Chunking options


je.list_history()
Upload history













Function
Description




je.query(text, kb="all", top_k=5, min_score=0.0)
Search. kb = name, list of names, or "all"



Returns list of dicts: {text, score, kb, file, chunk_index, model}.

Example
import justembed as je

je.register_workspace("~/my_docs")
je.begin(workspace="~/my_docs")

je.create_kb("docs")
je.add(kb="docs", path="report.txt")
results = je.query("summary", kb="docs", top_k=5)

title: JustEmbed
text:
JustEmbed (LENS — Language Embedder With No Synthesizer) is an offline-first tool for semantic search. It runs entirely on your machine: no cloud, no API keys, no GPU required.

E5-Small: General-purpose 384-dim embeddings (ONNX)
Custom models: Train domain-specific models (e.g. pyrexia ↔︎ fever) from your text
Knowledge bases: Multiple KBs, each with its own model
Web UI & Python API: Use the browser or import justembed as je

title: JustEmbed
text:
For Non-Technical Users
Upload documents through the web interface and search by meaning. No coding required. See how your text is chunked and embedded at each step.

title: JustEmbed

For Developers
A simple Python API lets you experiment with embeddings locally before moving to production vector databases.

Quick Start
pip install justembed
justembed begin --workspace ~/my_documents
Open http://localhost:5424 in your browser.

title: Getting Started
text:
Web Interface

Start the server:

justembed begin --workspace ~/my_documents

Open http://localhost:5424 in your browser.
On first run, the setup page asks you to choose a workspace folder. Pick or create a directory (e.g. ~/justembed_workspace).
From the main page you can:

Create knowledge bases
Train custom models
Upload documents (preview chunks, then embed)
Run queries

title: Getting Started
text:
Python API
import justembed as je

# Start server (registers workspace and opens app)
je.begin(workspace="~/my_docs", open_browser=True)

# Or run in background (e.g. in a notebook)
je.begin(workspace="~/my_docs", background=True)
Then use the Web UI at http://localhost:5424, or call the API:
je.create_kb("my_kb")
je.add(kb="my_kb", path="/path/to/document.txt")
results = je.query("search term", kb="my_kb")

title: Getting Started
text:
CLI Options
justembed begin --workspace ~/docs --port 5424 --host 127.0.0.1

--workspace, -w: Path to workspace folder
--port, -p: Port (default 5424)
--host: Bind address (default 127.0.0.1)

title: Guide
text:
A workspace is a folder that holds all your data:

kb/ — Knowledge bases (one DuckDB file per KB)
custom_models/ — Trained ONNX models
drop-in_models/ — Reserved for future use

The current workspace is stored in ~/.justembed/config.json. You can register multiple workspaces and switch between them in the Web UI.



Each KB is a DuckDB file. When you create a KB you choose:

E5-Small (default) — General-purpose 384-dim embeddings
Custom model — A model you trained on your own text

Different KBs can use different models.



Documents are split into chunks (default: max 300 tokens per chunk, merge threshold 50). Chunking is deterministic and structure-aware (paragraphs, headings). The Web UI shows a chunk preview before you embed.




Each chunk is turned into a vector (embedding). Similar meaning → similar vectors.
A query is embedded and compared to chunk embeddings (cosine similarity). Results are ranked by score (0.0–1.0).

title: Guide
text:
Web UI Flow

Setup — Choose workspace (first run).
Knowledge bases — Create a KB, select E5 or a custom model.
Train model (optional) — Upload text, set name and options, train. Saves to workspace/custom_models/<name>/.
Upload — Select file → Preview chunks → Apply chunking → Embed.
Query — Enter query, select KB(s), see ranked results with scores.

title: Guide
text:
Custom Models

Training data: Use a text file (or folder of .txt/.md) that contains the vocabulary and concepts you care about (e.g. medical terms).
Result: An ONNX model saved in workspace/custom_models/<name>/.
Limitation: Custom models are lexical (TF-IDF + MLP). They only “know” words that appeared in the training text. For semantic links (e.g. “hot” → temperature when “hot” never appeared), use E5.

title: Examples
text:
JustEmbed ships with two example medical text files you can use to see how training and KB content work.









File
Use




medical_embedding_demo.txt
Training the custom ONNX model (vocabulary)


medical_kb_documents.txt
Adding to a KB (documents to search)



Path (after install): inside the justembed package, e.g. justembed/examples/ (or copy from GitHub).




Train a custom model on medical_embedding_demo.txt (Web UI: Train Custom Model, or API: je.train_model("medical_demo", "path/to/medical_embedding_demo.txt")).
Create a KB with that custom model (or use E5).
Add to KB the file medical_kb_documents.txt (Upload → Preview → Apply chunking → Embed).
Query with e.g. fever, paracetamol, neutropenia, febrile neutropenia, UTI.





Max tokens: 300

Merge threshold: 50

Split by headings and paragraphs

medical_embedding_demo.txt yields 7 chunks; medical_kb_documents.txt yields 4 chunks.



Custom model (terms appear in training or KB text):

fever, pyrexia, paracetamol, acetaminophen, neutropenia, febrile neutropenia, antipyretic

E5 (semantic; can match concepts not literally in the text):

temperature regulation, low white blood cells, pain relief medicine, drug for fever

title: Examples
text:
Python Snippet
import justembed as je

je.register_workspace("~/justembed_demo")
je.begin(workspace="~/justembed_demo", background=True)

# Train on vocabulary text
je.train_model("medical_demo", "path/to/medical_embedding_demo.txt")

# Create KB and add documents to search
je.create_kb("medical_kb", model="medical_demo")
je.add(kb="medical_kb", path="path/to/medical_kb_documents.txt")

# Query
results = je.query("paracetamol", kb="medical_kb", top_k=5)
for r in results:
    print(f"{r['score']:.3f} | {r['text'][:80]}...")

title: Examples
text:
Understanding Results

Score: Cosine similarity (0.0–1.0). Higher = more similar to the query.
Custom model: Best when query words appeared in the training or document text.
E5: Can retrieve by meaning even when the exact query word is absent.
